title: Firefighting Terms
description: Sound the alarm and test your knowledge of the specialized language used by firefighters and fire services.

questions.question: What is a 'flashover' in firefighting?
options: A quick inspection of a fire scene
A brief power outage during a fire
The near-simultaneous ignition of most combustible materials in an enclosed area
A signal flare used by firefighters

questions.question: What does 'turnout gear' refer to?
options: Casual clothing worn off duty
The protective clothing and equipment worn by firefighters
The exit route from a fire station
Gear stored in a fire truck's turnout compartment

questions.question: What is a 'backdraft'?
options: The draft created by opening a window
A technique for reversing fire damage
Wind blowing behind a fire truck
An explosion caused by the sudden introduction of oxygen into a smoldering, oxygen-depleted fire

questions.question: What does 'SCBA' stand for?
options: Standard Crew Breathing Apparatus
Station Chief Broadcast Alert
Special Chemical Burn Aid
Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus

questions.question: What is 'overhaul' in firefighting?
options: Replacing old hoses
A complete equipment inspection
Repairing the fire truck
The process of searching for and extinguishing hidden fires after the main fire is controlled

questions.question: What is a 'Halligan bar'?
options: A metal barrier at a fire station
A reinforced support beam
A type of fire escape railing
A forcible entry tool with a fork, adze, and spike used to pry open doors and break through walls

questions.question: What does 'two-in, two-out' rule mean?
options: Two trucks enter, two exit at a scene
At least two firefighters must enter a hazardous area together while two remain outside as a rescue team
Shifts change every two hours
Two hoses in, two hoses out

questions.question: What is a 'fire triangle'?
options: A warning sign for flammable materials
A formation used by firefighters
The three elements needed for fire: heat, fuel, and oxygen
A triangular fire escape route

questions.question: What does 'exposure' mean in firefighting?
options: Being seen by the public
A building or area at risk of catching fire from an adjacent fire
Getting too much sun during an outdoor fire
A firefighter's experience level

questions.question: What is a 'tanker' in fire service?
options: A vehicle that carries a large supply of water to a fire scene
A storage container at the fire station
A type of fire hose nozzle
A firefighter's rank

questions.question: What does 'ventilation' accomplish during firefighting?
options: Removes heat, smoke, and toxic gases from a burning structure to improve visibility and conditions
Cools down the firefighters
Provides fresh air to the fire station
Blows out small fires

questions.question: What is a 'fire load'?
options: The capacity of a fire truck
The weight of firefighting equipment
The number of fire calls in a day
The total amount of combustible material in a given area

questions.question: What does 'strike team' mean in firefighting?
options: A demolition squad
A team that investigates arson
A specified combination of the same type of resources with a leader, assembled for a particular purpose
The first crew to arrive at a scene

questions.question: What is a 'Siamese connection' on a building?
options: A door connecting two buildings
A dual inlet pipe fitting that allows fire engines to pump water into a building's standpipe or sprinkler system
Twin chimneys joined together
A fire escape between two structures

questions.question: What does 'PASS' stand for when using a fire extinguisher?
options: Prepare, Activate, Spray, Secure
Pull, Aim, Squeeze, Sweep
Point, Apply, Shake, Spray
Push, Angle, Shoot, Stop
